events.title: Wellington Bombers Strike: Nine Aircraft Take Out 35 German Planes in Night Raid on Catania
events.description: 64. In spite of these reductions it was still found possible to operate   passage   Wellingtons occasionally from Malta. An especially successful attack was made on Catania aerodrome on the night of 15/16th January, when 35. German aircraft which had recently arrived were reported to have been destroyed on the ground by 9 Wellingtons.

events.title: Admiral Cunningham Submits Key Despatch to Admiralty Amidst WWII Mediterranean Operations
events.description: The following Despatch was submitted to The Lords Commissioners of the Admiralty on the 16th January, 1941, by Admiral Sir Andrew B. Cunningham, K.C.B., D.S.0., Commander-in-Chief, Mediterranean.

events.title: Historic Delivery of Six X-Craft Marks a New Era in Naval Warfare
events.description: 5. The six operational X-craft (X 5-X.10) were delivered from Messrs. Vickers Armstrong between the 31st December, 1942, and 16th January, 1943, and preliminary,plans were put in hand and advanced trainingveom-

events.title: Strategic Shift: British 53 Brigade Mobilized to Fortify Ayer Hitam Ahead of Indian Corps Command
events.description: At 1655 hrs. on the 16th January after visiting commanders in the forward area, I placed the 53 British Infantry Brigade under orders of the Commander 3 Indian! Corpstand ordered it to move during the following."hight to the Ayer Hitam area. The Commander 3 Indian Corps placed this brigade under the 11 Indian Division. One battalion (6 R. Norfolk) was immediately sent to hold the defile East of Bukit Payong, a dominating feature some I miles west 6f Yong*Peng, with a detachment at Parit Sulong Bridge some 5 miles further on.

events.title: Japanese Troops Vanish into Jungle: Batu Pahat's Bukit Banang Holds Secrets
events.description: Batu Pahat is dominated by the junglecovered Bukit Banang which lies to the south of the town. Into this area the Japanese troops who had landed at the lighthouse on the 16th January (see above) had disappeared.

events.title: Early Morning Incident Rocks Community: Details Unfold from January 16th Event
Desperate Measures: Singapore's Air Force Units Brace for Japanese Assault as Reinforcements Loom
events.description: 396. As has already been narrated in Section II of this Report, by the 16th January, 1942, all Air Force units in Malaya had been driven back to Singapore Island. Even with the existing strength, aerodromes on the island were already congested, they would become more congested when reinforcements, now well on their way, arrived. The scale of Japanese air attack against these aerodromes was increasing. It had become imperative to disperse more widely Extra elbow room was particularly desirable because H.M.S.   Indomitable,  with 48 Hurricanes on board, was due to arrive at the end of January. If bomber units could be transferred to Sumatra, not only would they be dispersed more safely, but fighter squadrons could then be distributed to all the aerodromes in Singapore. It was not realised at the time how soon three of those aerodromes  Tengah, Sembawang and Seletar would become untenable (para. 360).

events.title: R.A.F. Units Gear Up for Strategic Operations in the N.E.I. as Air Bases Established in Java and Sumatra
events.description: 356. During December, the first preparations had been made for operating R.A.F. Units in the N.E.I. (paras. 256-258). On qth January No, 153 M.U. was moved to Java, and on 16th January No. 225 (B) Group Heaciquarters was formed in Singapore and moved to Sumatra two days later in order to make preliminary arrangements for operating bombers from ae1odromes in that island.

events.title: Military Strategy Shifts: Bomber Units Set for Sumatra Transfer as New HQ Established in Singapore
events.description: 400. AH.Q. therefore decided, on the 16th January, that the time was becoming imminent when bomber units would have to be transferred to Sumatra. For this reason HQ 225 (B) Group was formed at Singapore on this date, and was sent to Palembang in Sumatra on the 18th January, 1942. Initial appointments made by A.H.Q. were:

events.title: Burma Rifles Clash with Japanese Forces Near Tavoy: Tensions Rising at Myitta
events.description: 70. Operations at Tavoy. On the 16th January two companies of the 6 Burma Rifles. came in contact with a Japanese force, estimated at about 100, at Myitta on the track leading from the north of Tavoy to the frontier.

events.title: Command Shift: GNA Takes Charge of 8th Division on January 16th
events.description: gna, Under command 8 thd, Div. 16th January.

events.title: 2nd New Zealand Division Relieved on January 16th: A New Chapter Begins!
Fleet Set Sail: Force 63 Departs Trincomalee with a Powerful Armada
events.description: (ii) Force 63, consisting of H. M. Ships INDOMITABLE (Flag of Flag Officer Commanding Aircraft Carriers, British Pacific Fleet), VICTORIOUS, ILLUSTRIOUS, INDEFATIGABLE, KING GEORGE V, ARGONAUT, BLACK PRINCE, EURYALUS, CEYLON, GRENVILLE (Captain (D), 25th Destroyer Flotilla), UNDINE, URSA, UNDAUNTED, KEMPENFELT (Captain (D), 27th Destroyer Flotilla), WAKEFUL, WHIRLWIND, WAGER, WESSEX and WHELP, sailed from Trincomalee at 1430 on Tuesday, 16th January, less CEYLON and WESSEX, who stayed to embark mail and radar spares respectively. CEYLON sailed to overtake at 1700.

events.title: 19 Indian Division Advances Southward from Mandalay: Key Tactical Movements at Thabeikkyin and Kyaukmyaung
events.description: (a) 19 Indian Division crossed north of Mandalay at Thabeikkyin (9th January) and Kyaukmyaung (16th January), as already described. They then, as will be shown later, advanced south on Mandalay, shifting their bridgehead south to Singu.
